content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" amends the 1986 Code and imposes a license fee on internet gambling operators. This Act also includes provisions for licensee information reporting. The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" adds a new subchapter to Chapter 36, imposing a license fee on internet gambling operators. The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" requires licensed internet gambling operators to pay a 2 percent fee on all funds deposited into betting accounts each month. Winnings deposits are excluded from this fee. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008 mandates licensed internet gambling operators to pay a 2 percent fee on all deposits into betting accounts monthly. Winnings deposits are exempt from this fee and the fees collected are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue. The internet gambling license fee is the sole responsibility of the operator and cannot be deducted from bettors' deposits. The Internet gambling license fee is the responsibility of the operator and cannot be deducted from bettors' deposits. The term 'Director' is defined in section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. The fee is treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. Information Returns section added to subchapter A of chapter 61 regarding special provisions. "SEC. 6039J. RETURNS OF INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide required information to the Secretary as prescribed by regulations, and maintain appropriate records. The information includes the operator's name, address, and other details determined by the Secretary. The subsection describes information required by the Secretary for Internet gambling operators, including name, address, tax information number, wager details, gross winnings, losses, tax withheld, and account balances for each person. The subsection outlines the required information for Internet gambling operators, including names, addresses, tax information numbers, wager details, gross winnings, losses, tax withheld, account balances, deposits, and withdrawals for each person. Operators must also provide a written statement to individuals with their contact information. The subsection requires Internet gambling operators to provide contact information and required details on returns for each person by January 31 of the following year. Clerical amendments are also made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36. The amendments require Internet gambling operators to submit returns by January 31 of the following year. Effective from December 31, 2008, the amendments apply to wagers made after that date. Additionally, withholding from certain gambling winnings is addressed in Section 3. The amendments to section 3402(q) require Internet gambling operators to report net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. Certain winnings are not exempt from withholding, as specified in paragraph (5). Definitions in subsection (q) have been updated accordingly. The amendments to section 3402(q) define "proceeds of net internet gambling winnings" as amounts withdrawn from an internet gambling account, and "net internet gambling winnings" as gross winnings. The term 'net Internet gambling winnings' refers to gross winnings from Internet wagers with licensed entities, minus the amount wagered. The definitions of 'Internet' and 'wager' are based on specific terms in the relevant section of the United States Code. Section 3406 is amended to include net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments, with operators treated as payors and bettors as payees. Terms are defined in accordance with section 3402(q)(7) of the United States Code. The amendment made by this section applies to wagers placed with a licensee after December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals is amended to include net Internet gambling income. An exemption for certain gambling winnings now includes wagers placed over the Internet. The amendment includes withholding tax on nonresident alien individuals for net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year, effective for wagers placed after December 31, 2008. SEC. 5. TAX ON WAGERS. Amendments to the tax on wagers include holding individuals liable for taxes on wagers placed with unlicensed persons and specifying territorial extent for taxation by US citizens or residents. Amendments made to the tax on wagers apply to wagers made after December 31, 2008.
